home.title: Unified Service Management (USM)
home.lead: A universal method to bring simplicity, control, and customer focus to any service organization.
introParagraphs: USM gives you one coherent management system for all your services – IT, facilities, HR, manufacturing, and more.
On this site you’ll find: executive overviews, practical guides, and chapter-by-chapter summaries of the USM method.

chapters.title: Chapter 1 – Why USM?
chapters.shortSummary: Explains why service organizations need a unified management method and introduces USM as an architectural answer.
keyPoints: Service organizations all share similar management problems, regardless of their domain.
Frameworks like ITIL, COBIT, Agile, etc., are helpful but fragmented.
USM provides a simple, generic management system that can host all these frameworks.

chapters.title: Chapter 2 – Principles of USM
chapters.shortSummary: Outlines the core principles that shape the USM method and its architecture.
keyPoints: Structure systems by segmenting them and managing their relations.
Standardize where possible; vary only where necessary.
The customer determines the quality of the service.
Big changes are realized in small steps.

chapters.title: Chapter 3 – Services and Value
chapters.shortSummary: Defines services, customers, users, facilities, and value creation in a co-creation perspective.
keyPoints: A service is support for someone’s activities.
Value is co-created: the provider, customer, and users all play a role.
Distinguishes use, specify, and realize domains in a service system.

chapters.title: Chapter 7 – The Service Organization
chapters.shortSummary: Shows how to structure a service organization: governance, domain separation, matrix organization, teams, and service desk.
keyPoints: Mission, vision, core values, strategy, goals, and policy set direction.
Governance creates the environment; management operates within it.
Planning & control works on strategic, tactical, and operational levels.
Domain separation splits specifying from realizing to improve control.
Process-based and workflow-based working separate design from execution.
Standardization is a core assurance technique.
RACI and clear profiles align people with processes.
Service desk acts as SPOC; self-service and standardization shift work left.
Beware of drama triangles and shadow services.

chapters.title: Chapter 8 – Technology Resources
chapters.shortSummary: Describes tools and templates that support USM, including the SDC tool and MIR.
keyPoints: Resources include coordination tools, automation tools, and non-automated templates.
Service Delivery Coordination (SDC) tool manages workflows and calls.
Managed Infrastructure Register (MIR) stores all managed components and their relations.
ERP vs Best-of-Breed tooling strategies: vendor lock-in vs modular flexibility.
Templates (forms, reports, RACI, catalogs, plans) are also key resources.

chapters.title: Chapter 9 – Deploying USM
chapters.shortSummary: Explains how to introduce USM in practice using sprints, change management, and related techniques.
keyPoints: USM can be deployed top-down, bottom-up, or both.
Formal deployment uses phases: intake, planning, set-up, improvement sprints, routine phase.
Internal project manager + optional USM coach + tool expert form the core project structure.
Organizational change management is crucial: attitude, behaviour, culture.
USM plays well with Agile, DevOps, Lean, Design Thinking, and other improvement techniques.
Shared service centers benefit from standardizing routines, tools, and structures first.
USM provides the management system that many standards (ISO, COBIT, etc.) expect.

guides.title: USM Executive Overview
guides.description: A concise slide deck for leadership that explains USM, why it matters, and how an organization can benefit.

guides.title: USM Practical Guide
guides.description: A more detailed, example-based companion for managers and practitioners implementing USM.
